>
> http://artificial-philosopher.blog-city.com/readblog.cfm?BID=17023
>
> A thorough explanation of why a REST solution is the best solution to
> the identity dilemma.
>
> I'd like to hear others thoughts on this.

Hmm... well, I am curious to see what will be in part 2 of the blog.  As for
this entry, I feel that some of the observations are either over-simplified
or plain wrong.  It's hard to agree with all of the blogger's conclusions
when it's based on somewhat flimsy arguments.

However, I do agree with the basic theme of the blog.  Using URIs and
documents to form a digital identity makes more sense than going the MS
Passport way.  At one level this is a description of the Web itself.  I have
a URI (http://www.seairth.com) which identifies documents which start to
give a rough idea of who I am.  This is true also for
http://www.microsoft.com and http://home.ccil.org/~cowan/.


Also, for those who are not aware of it, Thawte as the Web of Trust[1],
which is a a bottom-up certificate authority (CA) system.  Using SSL and the
WOT, a certain portion of this bottom-up REST-oriented digital identity
problem could be solved.  I'm not saying this is the solution to all of the
problems, just that there *are* others out there already attacking the
problem in a similar manner.

[1] http://www.thawte.com/html/COMMUNITY/wot/index.html
